nexttext:
i.\,e.\ if $\psi$ satisfies the Schr\"odinger equation as well as the vertex conditions then the same applies to $T \psi$.
Here $x_1$ is a coordinate in subgraph~1, and $x_2$ the corresponding coordinate (related by inversion) in subgraph~2. Applying (\ref{eq:tsymm})
twice shows $T^2=-1$.

Since this fact is essential for the following, a complementary approach shall be given establishing a direct correspondence between the experiment and a spin 1/2 system. The wave function in a quantum graph is subject to two constraints, continuity at the vertices and current conservation. In a microwave graph these constraints correspond to the well-known Kirchhoff rules governing electric circuits. They lead to a secular equation system having a solution only if the determinant of the corresponding matrix vanishes,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{array}[]{cc}T\psi(x_{1})&=+\psi^{*}(x_{2}),\\
T\psi(x_{2})&=-\psi^{*}(x_{1}),\end{array}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>ψ</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>ψ</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: where the matrix elements of $h(k)$ are given by

i.\,e.\ if $\psi$ satisfies the Schr\"odinger equation as well as the vertex conditions then the same applies to $T \psi$.
Here $x_1$ is a coordinate in subgraph~1, and $x_2$ the corresponding coordinate (related by inversion) in subgraph~2. Applying (\ref{eq:tsymm})
twice shows $T^2=-1$.

Since this fact is essential for the following, a complementary approach shall be given establishing a direct correspondence between the experiment and a spin 1/2 system. The wave function in a quantum graph is subject to two constraints, continuity at the vertices and current conservation. In a microwave graph these constraints correspond to the well-known Kirchhoff rules governing electric circuits. They lead to a secular equation system having a solution only if the determinant of the corresponding matrix vanishes,

nexttext:
where $C_{ij}=1$, if nodes $i$ and $j$ are connected, and $C_{ij}=0$ otherwise. $l_{ij}$ is the length of the bond connecting nodes $i$ and $j$. $\varphi_{ij}$ is a phase resulting, e.\,g., from a vector potential and breaks TRS if present. The equation holds for Neumann boundary conditions at all nodes, the situation found in the experiment. Details can be found in \cite{kot99a}. The solutions of the determinant condition (\ref{eq:det}) generate the spectrum of the graph.

Applied to the graph of Fig.~\ref{fig:graph} the secular matrix $h(k)$ may be written as
prevtext: where the matrix elements of $h(k)$ are given by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="h_{ij}(k)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{cc}-\sum\limits_{n\neq i}C_{in}\cot(kl_{in})&%
i=j\\
C_{ij}e^{-{\imath\varphi_{ij}}}\left[\sin(kl_{ij})\right]^{-1}&i\neq j\end{%
array}\right." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>h</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>≠</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></munder><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>cot</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>l</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ı</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>φ</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>l</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>≠</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mi/></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $h_{\mathrm{dis}}$ is the secular matrix for the disconnected subgraphs, and $v$ describes the connecting bonds. The solutions of the determinant condition (\ref{eq:det}) generate the spectrum of the graph.

where $h_{\mathrm{dis}}$ is the secular matrix for the disconnected subgraphs, and $v$ describes the connecting bonds. It is convenient to introduce an order of rows and columns according to $\{1, 2, \dots,n;\bar{1}, \bar{2}, \dots, \bar{n}\}$, where the numbers without bar refer to the vertices of subgraph 1, and the numbers with bar to those of subgraph 2. $h_{\mathrm{dis}}$ may then be written as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="h_{\mathrm{dis}}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}h_{0}&\cdot\\
\cdot&h_{0}^{*}\\
\end{array}\right)" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>dis</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>⋅</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>⋅</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><msubsup><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn><mo>*</mo></msubsup></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="[\tilde{h}(k)]_{nm}=\left[\mathrm{Re}(h_{0})_{nm}+v_{nm}\right]{\bf 1}-\mathrm%
{Im}(h_{0})_{nm}{\bf\tau_{z}}-v_{n\bar{m}}{\bf\tau_{y}}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>Re</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mn>𝟏</mn></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>Im</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>𝐳</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>𝐲</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
The determinant is not changed by this rearrangement of rows and columns, $\mathrm{det}[h(k)]=\mathrm{det}[\tilde{h}(k)]$. The matrix elements $[\tilde{h}(k)]_{nm}$ commute with $C{\bf\tau_y}$, where $C$ denotes the complex conjugate, and hence the whole matrix commutes with $T=\mathrm{diag}(C{\bf\tau_y}\, \dots,C{\bf\tau_y})$, where $T$ squares to minus one, $T^2=-1$. This is exactly the situation found for spin 1/2 systems, and just as in such systems a two-fold Kramers degenerate spectrum is expected showing the signatures of the GSE provided the system is chaotic, see e.\,g. Chapter 2 of Ref.~\onlinecite{haa01b}.

The requirements defined by Joyner et\,al. \cite{joy14} to realize graphs with GSE symmetry pose some challenges. Since we did not know of a simple way to achieve phase shifts of $\pm\pi/2$ along the bonds, we proceeded in a somewhat different way and instead built two geometrically identically subgraphs, but with two circulators of opposite sense of rotation within the two subgraphs. A circulator is a microwave device introducing directionality: Microwaves pass from port 1 to port 2, from port 2 to port 3, and from port 3 to port 1. The result is the same as with the $\pm\pi/2$ shifts: the circulators break TRS, resulting in identical GUE spectra for the two disconnected subgraphs, but with an opposite sense of propagation within the respective subgraphs. Again the two subgraphs may thus be described in terms of a secular matrix $h_0$ and its complex conjugate $h_0^*$, respectively.

The phase difference between the two connecting bonds is adjustable by means of mechanical phase shifters which in reality, however, do not change the phase but the length. This approach has the obvious shortcoming that for a given length change $\Delta l$ the phase shift $\Delta\varphi$ depends on frequency $\nu$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\bf 1}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}1&\cdot\\
\cdot&1\\
\end{array}\right),\quad{\bf\tau_{z}}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}-\imath&\cdot\\
\cdot&\imath\\
\end{array}\right),\quad{\bf\tau_{y}}=\left(\begin{array}[]{cc}\cdot&-1\\
1&\cdot\\
\end{array}\right)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mn>𝟏</mn><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>⋅</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>⋅</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>𝐳</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>ı</mi></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>⋅</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>⋅</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mi>ı</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>τ</mi><mi>𝐲</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>⋅</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>⋅</mo></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
The determinant is not changed by this rearrangement of rows and columns, $\mathrm{det}[h(k)]=\mathrm{det}[\tilde{h}(k)]$. The matrix elements $[\tilde{h}(k)]_{nm}$ commute with $C{\bf\tau_y}$, where $C$ denotes the complex conjugate, and hence the whole matrix commutes with $T=\mathrm{diag}(C{\bf\tau_y}\, \dots,C{\bf\tau_y})$, where $T$ squares to minus one, $T^2=-1$. This is exactly the situation found for spin 1/2 systems, and just as in such systems a two-fold Kramers degenerate spectrum is expected showing the signatures of the GSE provided the system is chaotic, see e.\,g. Chapter 2 of Ref.~\onlinecite{haa01b}.

The requirements defined by Joyner et\,al. \cite{joy14} to realize graphs with GSE symmetry pose some challenges. Since we did not know of a simple way to achieve phase shifts of $\pm\pi/2$ along the bonds, we proceeded in a somewhat different way and instead built two geometrically identically subgraphs, but with two circulators of opposite sense of rotation within the two subgraphs. A circulator is a microwave device introducing directionality: Microwaves pass from port 1 to port 2, from port 2 to port 3, and from port 3 to port 1. The result is the same as with the $\pm\pi/2$ shifts: the circulators break TRS, resulting in identical GUE spectra for the two disconnected subgraphs, but with an opposite sense of propagation within the respective subgraphs. Again the two subgraphs may thus be described in terms of a secular matrix $h_0$ and its complex conjugate $h_0^*$, respectively.

The phase difference between the two connecting bonds is adjustable by means of mechanical phase shifters which in reality, however, do not change the phase but the length. This approach has the obvious shortcoming that for a given length change $\Delta l$ the phase shift $\Delta\varphi$ depends on frequency $\nu$:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta\varphi=k\Delta l=\frac{2\pi\nu}{c}\Delta l" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>φ</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ν</mi></mrow><mi>c</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></mrow></math>
